text: Thanks for arch doc. Out of 3 simplifications offered I vote for 1st: only implement web node.
(For 1st pass)
<@U08D641AP> has a huge PR to pull in converse into the main "datt" repo ... i'm reviewing now but would appreciate other developers' input (ping <@U08DD8LNP> <@U08ERPTQF> )
it's WIP, or perhaps more accurately RFC, so please be brutal with your review :simple_smile:
I’ll take a look tomorrow
I'm reading <@U07GDL0H5>'s architecture & reviewing <@U08D641AP>'s PR
just saw that link thanks <@U08ERPTQF> looks like a really good overview to me
I’d also mention maidsafe in addition to ipfs, my worry with both of those is that it might put more weight/power on the full nodes

but perhaps some sort of hybrid system where IPFS/maidsafe is more persistant storage and light nodes replicate more recent content for more distributed access less reliant on full nodes could be an interesting approach

actually as a general approach that might be a really interesting separation of concerns.   there is likely a higher cost to storing data in ipfs/maidsafe than ephemeral browser p2p storage.   Maybe we only long-term persist content that gets well received.

we could build out the browser nodes as short term ephemeral content distribution, and put the responsibility of longer term storage on the full nodes.  In such a way that the full nodes are not necessary for the operation of the light nodes except as a rendevous
then we could develop the light nodes first and treat the full node as a second phase as I expect that part might get more involved.
this might also help with anonymity if the light nodes are passing/bouncing around content before it reaches a full node for longer term storage.
heading to bed, g'night everyone
gnight
goodnight
<https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet>

attachments.title: HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet
attachments.text: ZeroNet - Decentralized websites using Bitcoin crypto and BitTorrent network

text: <@U08DD8LNP>: I agree that light nodes will mostly deal with the least interesting content, full nodes are likely to prioritise content that is likely to be interesting and derive some value
I wouldn’t call that the least interesting content, just the most recent/active content
basically the light nodes are our RAM and the full nodes are our hard drive
(in this model that I just came up with at 2am)

I mean it hasn't get become interesting to the nodes - however the nodes decide what is interesting
e.g. content that has been listed by one or more collectives becomes more interesting, as does content that has met a threshold of votes in a given duration, and certainly if there is a bounty the content is interesting to the full node
maybe nodes decide to pull in content from the light nodes once they hit a btc threshold
but not all content can be interesting straight away, and depending on the network dynamics we could end up with a majority of content being ephemeral between the light nodes
which isn’t necessarily a bad thing.  You kind of end up with a chan/reddit hybrid at that point
if we could structure rewards such that your upvote went partially to the host as well as the author then the whole system could likely be self correcting
leave it up to full nodes to decide their own metrics of what to keep available for hosting to maximize their own gains
precisely, I keep talking about bounties for exactly that reason, but it's still too abstract for my liking
like if they are bearing the cost of storing something in a distributed system then they would have the ability to see returns
call them fares :wink:
how do we connect: the user making the vote -> the author who posted -> the node
seems like a job for smart contracts but I don’t know how you would structure it offhand
I was thinking payment channels, but <@U07GDL0H5> has challenged my thinking in that regard
A lot of small smart contracts
breaking it down you need the author to be able to prove they posted a thing and connecte it to an address.  and you need the host to be able to prove they bore the burden of hosting
and ideally a way for other transmitting nodes along the path to also stake a claim
I see it that the upstream nodes should have staked a claim already, and there is less left for the downstream nodes
idk if such a thing is really possible with standard bitcoin script though
You can even let the full node and author agree on the split on upvotes; More popular the author lesser the percentage and vice-versa;
but on the other hand, if we have enough full bitcoin nodes we can say fuck the standard transactions and possibly do more interesting contracts
hehe, or at that point Lightning is mature enough to implement on the full nodes
from a personal point, lightning might be too heavy for this, but might offer the best bet to handle things cleanly

the other thing I'm trying to work through: given a sufficiently large user base, the odds that any two users will have a vote transaction between them is increasingly small. So if a single vote is only a few bits then there will be a lot of < dust sized transactions that never get committed.
<@U08ERPTQF>: yeah this is one of my main worries with going bitcoin for this
or the other way could be to do it with a exchange type of system
I think dust limits and fees are going to be quite prohibitive to participation at the level we really want
there almost needs to be a participant on the network that aggregates the commitments in an escrow manner (again smart contracts)
making that aggregation secure in this system would be challenging
<https://www.reddcoin.com/papers/PoSV.pdf> is a pretty interesting whitepaper btw
cool I'll read that
got to head out for a bit... Ciao
<@U08DD8LNP>: PoSV does indeed have interesting economic properties that encourage its use (hence velocity) - I'm not yet sure whether this would benefit the Datt model
<@U08MT2FTL|jeff> has joined the channel
Morning all. Saw a commit removing 'browser based' for the initial MVP. Wording change or scrap the browser part for now?
Assuming it's just a semantics change.
It is a semantics change at this moment. The goal is to build a system which will move beyond the browser. So, I removed the word browser
the first step will most probably be the browser setup but we need to get the mobile platforms either natively or thru' react native or something to that effect
<@U08DH3ESU>: Sounds great. ty
<@U08DH3ESU>:  I think the words browser based are still important for people coming to understand our project. Otherwise people (@jeff included) might think we are building native apps to start with

i think adding "browser based" is good for tech savvy people. if the statement is intended to appeal to them, then "browser based" is explanatory. to people who aren't tech savvy, i'm not sure they need to care it's "browser based". i'm fine with either being in the docs.

i think “browser based” thinking is holding you guys back. stick an HTTP API in front of anything and it’ll work in a browser. restricting yourselves to the tools that are available in a browser that was mostly built for centralized apps might not be the best
Building a great browser-based app is going to be a slog. We ended up just going with Electron wrapping our Python code.
This allows us to build web based code but have a standalone app
It sounded like you guys were against a download app though
Goal is to not require downloads, that's why so much work is focused on the full nodes
Of course other clients will be built with even more difficult features, so some users will opt to install a client

<@U08CZDYB1>: the browser based focus is IMO one of our core differentiators from something like aether.  If we want a wide userbase we want as little friction as possible, and additionally that wide userbase should all be contributing to the health of the network if possible

we have web sockets and webrtc and those should be enough in theory to do what we want.  I have many years experience in building very complex browser apps.  If the p2p networking can be done within the restrictions of browsers then we can totally do this.
JS has become a pretty decent platform out of necessity, and frameworks like ember exist to bring more native-app style development models to long running browser apps
browser-based is a differentiator, but my hunch is that it will be a negative one. browser-accessible is a good requirement. browser-based might not be, but who knows
it’s not our intention to limit clients to the browser, just at a minimum we want a browser to be as full a network participant as possible
so maybe browser based is bad wording.  browser accessible p2p networking maybe?
why is having browsers be full network participants a useful requirement?
low barrier to entry.
casual users can get involved
browser-accessible meets those criteria
this may all be a huge distraction, but it seems like an overly strict restriction to me that’s going to require you guys to write tons of new code
which could succeed! but writing new code is hard
if it's in javascript, 90% of the code is the same between browser and server :simple_smile:

my point is that there’s lots of infrastructure for building decentralized apps out there (ethereum, IPFS, whisper, maidsafe, etc), and all those things are browser-accessible but not browser-based, so they’re being ignored
time will be spent reimplementing what they do, and the reimplementations probably won’t be as good
that, to me, is a shame
I've got Maki's messaging framework compiling with browserify :simple_smile:
the browser now receives all modifications to share state with the server via WebRTC
s/share/shared
hey <@U08DD8LNP> , reading through the ember source code, is this based on ES 2015? i see "imports" and what not, and "ember-babel" ... that would make me happy if so :simple_smile:
yes it supports developing in es2015 syntax and will transpile
nice!
yeah in general the ember community tries to support where things are going not just where they are
awesome
promises have been integral to ember for like 2 years now since before they were adopted as standard
I expect they will be doing more of that sort of thing in 2.0 as ember-cli is moving from an optional thing to a core aspect of the framework
you can easily get SASS/LESS compilation going as well
i have a WIP PR to pull in the UI into the server: <https://github.com/dattnetwork/datt/pull/13>

text: it took a while to make this work and only works in io.js 1.xx (since that's what ember supports)

the intent being that there is a main "app" that runs both in the server and in the client that connects to the datt p2p network and handles the database ... that is the "app" that i had started working on ... and that can be built directly into the client
would appreciate input on this. there are other approaches as well, such as keeping client/server separate. i'm (obviously) in favor of unifying them because i think it will make development easier.
I am very much in favor of keeping the repos separate
and pulling in the server as a dependency if you want to make things easier
generally most in the ember community have solidified on the idea that the UI app should be a separate repo from whatever API is powering it
you can set up some server integrations with ember-cli though but I’m having trouble finding good docs for that.  The other easy approach is you can start with ember server —proxy <http://yourserver>
and it will proxy any ajax requests through to that
IMO that main “app” that runs both places and connects to the network and handles the database should be a totally separated library
pulled in via NPM for the server and via bower for the client.

The intent is that if you download this repo on npm, you have the 
"full" app, which you can run a full datt node, as well as the UI. You 
can also run just the client right now with "ember server”. — we should be able to achieve that with these things split up as modules
ok, i'm fine with that ... we can keep them separate
<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QJ9r4gM20ME>

text: <http://discuss.emberjs.com/t/new-app-w-rails-same-repo-or-separate/5744> It will make even more sense if someone starts trying to do a more performant version of the backend in go or something

attachments.title: New app w/ Rails. Same repo or separate?
attachments.text: First, hello. Am new here. Second, I tried to look around before I asked a potentially stupid question, but I haven' found anything clear. I'm looking to build an Ember.JS app with a Rails API back-end. Should I treat these as two separate apps or combine them into one codebase/repo? I've found at least one gem that helps with this but seem to run into less than definitive references here and there that it may not be the thing to do. I'm hoping the community can help me out. Thanks, N8 ...
attachments.fallback: Ember.JS: New app w/ Rails. Same repo or separate?

text: also ember and ember-cli are pretty opinionated, they are gonna dictate the project structure of the UI for the most part and trying to fight it is a losing battle.  There are conventions for integrating some server stuff for dev, but I can’t find good docs for it, I can code up a simple example though that will let you define express handlers in the same instance that serves the UI in development

I haven’t looked into their build process but whatever snoocore is doing works out really well in my experience: <https://github.com/trevorsenior/snoocore>  I’ve used that app from both node via NPM and ember via bower works great

attachments.title: trevorsenior/snoocore
attachments.text: snoocore - A minimal and complete JavaScript driver for the reddit API.

text: The other advantage of this approach is it makes it easier for people to explore alternative UIs in angular or react etc...
